factoid: The crowd gathered at the large table.
The large table was attended by seventy-year-old magnates who were gray-haired or bald.
The magnates were uniformed and besashed.
Pierre had seen almost all of the magnates in their own homes.
Pierre had seen almost all of the magnates playing Boston at clubs.
The crowd advanced to the table while an incessant hum of voices filled the air.
The orators spoke one after another while pressed against the high backs of the chairs.
Sometimes two orators spoke together.
Those standing behind the orators noticed omissions in the speeches and hastened to supply them.
Others in the heat and crush racked their brains to find thoughts and hastened to utter them.
Pierre knew the old magnates.
The old magnates sat and turned to look at one another.
The old magnates' faces mostly expressed that they found the environment very hot.
Pierre felt excited.
The general desire among the crowd to show readiness to go to all lengths was expressed in tones and looks.
The general desire among the crowd infected Pierre.
Pierre did not renounce his opinions.
Pierre felt himself somewhat to blame.
Pierre wished to justify himself.
Pierre said that it would be more purposeful to make sacrifices when they know what is needed.
One of the old men nearest to Pierre looked around, but his attention was diverted by an exclamation at the other side of the table.
One man shouted that Moscow will be surrendered and that she will be their expiation.
Another man cried that he is the enemy of mankind.
Another man said he would speak.
A man said to the gentlemen that they are crushing him.
Count Rostopchín had a protruding chin and alert eyes.
Count Rostopchín wore the uniform of a general with a sash over his shoulder.
Count Rostopchín entered the room.
Count Rostopchín stepped briskly to the front of the crowd of gentry.
Count Rostopchín said that the Emperor would be here in a moment.
Count Rostopchín said he was straight from the palace.
Count Rostopchín said that there is little need for discussion given the position.
Count Rostopchín said the Emperor has summoned them and the merchants.
Count Rostopchín said millions will pour forth from the merchants' hall.
Count Rostopchín said their business is to supply men and not spare themselves.
Count Rostopchín said that is the least they can do.
A conference took place among the magnates sitting at the table.
The consultation passed more than quietly.
The sound of the magnates saying "I agree" or "I too am of that opinion" had a mournful effect.
The secretary was told to write down the resolution of the Moscow nobility and gentry.
The resolution stated that the Moscow nobility and gentry would furnish ten fully equipped men out of every thousand serfs.
The resolution was similar to what the Smolénsk gentry had done.
The chairs made a scraping noise.
The gentlemen who had conferred rose with apparent relief.
The gentlemen walked up and down arm in arm to stretch their legs and converse in couples.
A sudden cry of "The Emperor! The Emperor!" resounded through the halls and the throng hurried to the entrance.
The Emperor entered the hall through a broad path between two lines of nobles.
Every face expressed respectful, awe-struck curiosity.
Pierre stood far off and could not hear all of the Emperor's words.
Pierre understood that the Emperor spoke of the danger threatening the empire and of the hopes he placed on the Moscow nobility.
Pierre was answered by a voice that informed him of the resolution that had just arrived.
The Emperor said "Gentlemen!" with a quivering voice.
The Emperor said "I never doubted the devotion of the Russian nobles, but today it has surpassed my expectations."
The Emperor said "I thank you in the name of the Fatherland."
The Emperor said "Gentlemen, let us act!"
The Emperor said "Time is most precious."
The Emperor ceased speaking.
The crowd began pressing around the Emperor.
Rapturous exclamations were heard from all sides.
Count Rostóv said "Yes, most precious... a royal word."
Count Rostóv stood at the back.
Count Rostóv had heard hardly anything.
Count Rostóv understood everything in his own way.
